fields.description:
h3. Summary

When a Crucible Project is created and there's no repository to be set as the default, either because there's no repository yet in FishEye or all of them are stopped/disabled, Crucible does not add a default repository. The problem with that is, Crucible needs the default repository to be able to create hyperlinks to the repositories inside the activity page for that project. Since there's no default, there's no hyperlink, no matter how many repositories you add to the project.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Go to {{Administration >> Repository Settings >> Repositories}} and make sure there's currently no active FishEye repository.
# Go to {{Administration >> Project Settings >> Projects}} and create a Crucible project (e.g. Testing Project).
!create_project_no_repo.png|thumbnail!
(i) Note that under *Content* there will be no _Default Repository_ selected (i.e. blank field).
# Go back to {{Administration >> Repository Settings >> Repositories}} and turn the repositories back on.
# Go to the {{Administration >> Project Settings >> Projects}} page, locate the Testing Project and under *Actions* click the Fisheye content option.
# Add one of your repositories to the project (e.g. Github).
!add_project_to_repo.png|thumbnail!
# From the top navigation bar, click {{Project >> All projects}}.
!project_no_default_repo.png|thumbnail!
(i) From the list of Projects you'll see there's no *Repository* for the Project you just created (e.g. Testing Project).
# Access the Project.
!repo_without_hyperlink.png|thumbnail!
(i) Unlike the reviews, the repositories are greyed out.
# Go to the {{Administration >> Project Settings >> Projects}} page and access the project (e.g. Testing Project).
# You'll see there's a _Default Repository_ now, even though you never selected one. This is misleading because, in fact, there's no default repository for that Project. Since there isn't a _None_ option for that field, Crucible displays the first repository in the list of active repositories. Now select one of the repositories from that list and *Save* the page.
!edit_crucible_project.png|thumbnail!
# From the top navigation bar, click {{Project >> All projects}}.
!project_with_default_repo.png|thumbnail!
(i) From the list of Projects you'll see that your Project (e.g. Testing Project) does have a *Repository* now.
# Access the Project, you'll see that all of the repositories associated to this Project are now hyperlinked.
!repo_with_hyperlink.png|thumbnail!

h3. Workaround

Access the Project from the {{Administration >> Project Settings >> Projects}} page, select a _Default Repository_ for this project and hit *Save*. All of the repositories associated to your Project will now be hyperlinked.
fields.summary: Repositories are not hyperlinked by default inside Project activity page

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The review progress is not updated to reflect the addition of a new file being attached to the review leaving the participant review status as Complete.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create and start a Crucible review
 # Under a second user account, join the review
 # Under a second user account, mark the review as Complete
 # Attach file to the review
 ## Select Edit Details > Add Content > Attachments
 ## Upload file and select Done
 # Refresh review

h3. Expected Results

The participant role should be updated from *{{Reviewer - Complete}}* to *{{Reviewer % Reviewed}}*
h3. Actual Results

The participant role remains as *{{Reviewer - Complete}}*

!image-2017-08-11-16-58-16-633.png|thumbnail!
h3. Workaround

After uploading a file, it will immediately appear in the *{{Existing Attachments}}* section with a check-mark.

Simply uncheck and recheck the file and the Participant role will be updated.
fields.summary: Review progress does not update when new attachment is added

fields.description:
h4. Summary

Users of review are not uncompleted when attaching new file to Crucible review
h4. Environment

Crucible 4.3.2 or 4.4.1
h4. Steps to Reproduce
 # Make sure "Uncomplete review if revision is added" is selected for your user, userA.
 # Create file with text.
 # Create a review under any Project.
 # In Add Content, add Attachments.
 # Choose and upload file created. Start Review.
 # Edit Details and add a reviewer.
 # Login as new reviewer, userB, and complete the review.
 # Login as userA and see that userB completed review.
 # Change file with text, then attach the file to the review as userA.
 # Note that the file does have a diff.

h4. Expected Results

UserB shows as Uncompleted
h4. Actual Results

UserB shows as Completed
h4.
fields.summary: Users of review are not uncompleted when attaching new file to Crucible review

fields.description:
As the language is getting more popular and can be easily added to existing Java and Android projects, I think it would be nice to support its syntax in Fisheye/Crucible out of the box.

I am aware that it is possible to add it manually:

[|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/configure-syntax-highlighting-for-non-standard-file-extensions-300811223.html] [https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/configure-syntax-highlighting-for-non-standard-file-extensions-300811223.html]

However, this sounds only like a workaround as the file would be overwritten after each update.

Judging from the number of similar requests for other languages, you could also consider giving the users easier way of configuring new languages, like through a plugin system.
fields.summary: Syntax highlighting for Kotlin

fields.description:
h3. Summary

A regression in Apache HTTPClient shipped with Crucible 4.4.1 causes a ClassCastException when attempting to authenticate against Crucible and the SSL certificate for the server contains ASN.1 encoded entries for the Subject Alternate Name.
* https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HTTPCLIENT-1836


h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the fisheye log file:
{noformat}
Caused by: java.lang.ClassCastException: [B cannot be cast to java.lang.String
	at org.apache.http.conn.ssl.DefaultHostnameVerifier.getSubjectAltNames(DefaultHostnameVerifier.java:309) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
	at org.apache.http.conn.ssl.DefaultHostnameVerifier.verify(DefaultHostnameVerifier.java:112) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
	at org.apache.http.conn.ssl.DefaultHostnameVerifier.verify(DefaultHostnameVerifier.java:99) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
	at org.apache.http.conn.ssl.SSLConnectionSocketFactory.verifyHostname(SSLConnectionSocketFactory.java:463) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
	at org.apache.http.conn.ssl.SSLConnectionSocketFactory.createLayeredSocket(SSLConnectionSocketFactory.java:397) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
	at org.apache.http.conn.ssl.SSLConnectionSocketFactory.connectSocket(SSLConnectionSocketFactory.java:355) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
{noformat}
 

h3.Workaround
* Regenerate the certificates so that it does not contain any ASN.1 DER encoded values.
fields.summary: HTTPClient throws ClassCastException when user(s) attempts to login

fields.description:
We've had FishEye integrated with our TeamForge repositories for a while, and it has worked well.

Normally, the time is about 10-15 seconds for a page load. Today, we were seeing 2-3 minutes by multiple users. Sometimes even more.
Is there anything that can be done?
Any reason or cause for this sudden increase in response time?
Any type of garbage collection/speedup that can be done on the back end?

fields.description:
The MultiPathResource class in Atlassian FishEye and Crucible, before version 4.4.1 allows anonymous remote attackers to read arbitrary files via a path traversal vulnerability when FishEye or Crucible are running on the Microsoft Windows operating system.

h3. Workaround

Create {{$FISHEYE_INST\content}} directory, which can be empty but must exists.

*Note: * This only affects windows versions - I tested on OSX and it is not vulnerable to this issue.
fields.summary: Anonymous local file system access on Windows OS - CVE-2017-9511

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The default limit of files that can be added to a review is not enforced.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install FishEye 4.3.1
# Create a repository with 500 files in a revision
# Create a review for that revision

h3. Expected Results

Review creation should fail with a message saying there are too many files. 

h3. Actual Results

The review is created.
 
h3.Workaround

Add {{system.properties}} file in your {{$FISHEYE_INST}} directory with the following contents:

{noformat}
crucible.review.content.size.limit=400
{noformat}
fields.summary: Default file limit is not enforced

fields.description:
# It would be helpful to be able to email/message all reviewers within a review without using an external tool. This is handy when notifying participants for a change to the review (e.g., additional artifact, peer review reminders, etc.). With the current Crucible, we have to set up the review, and then go to gmail to send an email by manually adding the individual participants to the recipients. I would like a button that allows us to compose and send an email to all participants from Crucible. 
 # It would be helpful to be able to send out a Google meeting invite for new peer reviews in Crucible. This would allow us to set up a meeting and send out a gmail invite to reduce the need to set up a review followed by going to Google Calendar to send out a meeting invite with the participants.
fields.summary: "Email all reviewers" & "Review meeting invites"

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Crucible truncates title too much if it only contains space near heading point.
 This behaviour's severity is more serious for non latin char users because they don't use space as [word divider|https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Word_divider&oldid=773746279].
h3. Environment

Verified by major latest browsers
 * Chrome Version 58.0.3029.110 (64-bit)
 * Safari Version 10.1.1 (11603.2.5)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create review whose title is _"AT-12345: 諸行無常の響きあり、沙羅双樹の花の色、盛者必衰のことわりをあらはす、おごれる人も久しからず、ただ春の夜の夢のごとし、猛きものも終には滅びぬ、ひとへに風の前の塵に同じ"_
 # Close the review
 # Check the title is excessively truncated. In this case, it will be _"AT-12345:..."_.

!Screenshot 2017-05-30 17.46.53.png|thumbnail! !Screenshot_2017-05-30_17_24_14.png|thumbnail! !Screenshot_2017-05-30_17_24_52.png|thumbnail!
h3. Expected Results

Truncate a proper amount of title.
h3. Actual Results

The first ASCII chars will be rendered.
 It is more likely to be excessively truncated if review status is closed.
h3. Notes

I verified that this behaviour depends on some conditions such as:
 * Title length should be long enough: 81+ chars
 * Title should only contains space in heading point
 * Review status affects rendering:
 ** Chrome: it happens only if review status is closed
 ** Safari: it happens even review status is open/closed

This behaviour occurs not only in multibyte chars but also ASCII chars if it only contains space near heading point such as:
_AT-12345: TXUAARDCGTZJXKJVSCZOPYZDYSNMCAYFGVHAFRJKIHJJBZBMXRUUDJWOENOHECCPXUFTWKUDRNCFJFVB_

h3. Workaround
 * Click title to edit if review status is open. This isn't applicable for closed review.
fields.summary: Title gets excessively truncated if it only contains space near heading point

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When adding a user as a reviewer, if more than one user shares the same name, then only one result is returned.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a user with a display name of {{Jeff Thomas}} and username {{jefft}}
# Create another user with display name {{Jeff Thomas}} and username {{jeffth}}
# Create a new review
# When adding a reviewer, search for {{jeff}}

h3. Expected Results

Both Jeff Thomas' are returned

h3. Actual Results

Only one user is returned

h3.Workaround

# Have the user that does not appear navigate directly to the review and join it
# Change one of the user's display name so that it's unique
fields.summary: When adding a reviewer only one user is returned if two or more share the same name

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Cannot transition a review linked to a JIRA issue from within Crucible to a closed status.
 "Unspecified Error" is seen in the Crucible GUI and the issue is not transitioned in JIRA.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In JIRA add a custom field of type "User Picker" (single/multi user, doesn't matter) to a transition screen
 # Ensure this field is non-empty (i.e. set it by doing a transition and selecting a user)
 # Try to perform this transition from Crucible

h3. Expected Results
 - The issue is transitioned/closed in both Crucible and JIRA

h3. Actual Results

Transition will fail, because the User type used by the user picker field has a boolean flag isActive. [ComplexIssueInputFieldValueJsonGenerator#generateFieldValueForJson|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/jira-rest-java-client/src/1767eb57e03b9de3a202ce4daf779d6632a4f6a0/core/src/main/java/com/atlassian/jira/rest/client/internal/json/gen/ComplexIssueInputFieldValueJsonGenerator.java?at=jira-rest-java-client-parent-2.0.0-m31&fileviewer=file-view-default#ComplexIssueInputFieldValueJsonGenerator.java-41] that is used underneath cannot serialise boolean values during communication with the JIRA server.

h3. Workaround 1

Remove custom field Watchers from "Close" transition screen.
h3. Workaround 2

If you need this field when closing issues in JIRA, you can create a copy of the "Close" transition, and ensure that the copied transition does not have a transition screen. Then use that transition from Crucible.
h3. Workaround 3

View the issue in JIRA and close it there, rather than through Crucible

fields.description: It would be helpful if it was possible to set up multiple "default reviewers" groups. Group A would contain one set of users, and group B would contain another set of users. Upon creation of a review, the user would be able to select which group should review the code.
fields.summary: Allow for multiple "default reviewers" groups

fields.description:
I get complaints all the time from my users that they don't want to transition the linked JIRA issue when closing a code review.  or the opposite.. that it didn't transition the linked issue when they hit the close link.

While it is documented how to transition an issue the dialog that comes up after closing a review is not intuitive; that it won't actually transition an issue unless you click on the transition issue dropdown.    

Most users (mine at least)  believe that clicking the close link will
 # close the review.
 # transition the issue to the status in the "transition issue" dropdown.

Many users have been actually transition issues backwards and then going into JIRA to reset it back, not realizing they can just hit the close or dashboard link instead.  

The preferred solution would be not to default the "transition issue" dropdown and leave it blank, or some message like "No Transition", "do nothing".. etc.

other options.
 * Update the documentation to reflect that the close link actually does (aka.. closes the dialog only) so that we can direct users to it.
 * or provide an info message (which is what I will probably do in a plugin to correct this misunderstanding)
 * or provide a "close review" and "close review & transition" workflow option when a review is linked to a Jira.

I put the most current release in the affects versions but it goes back to at least 3.4 which is the oldest documentation I could find.
fields.summary: After closing a Crucible review the pop to transition a Jira is not intuitive.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

PDF product documentation for FishEye, Crucible, and Confluence are hosted in the Atlassian Cloud (Bitbucket.org) and redirected to Amazon AWS while the other product documentation is hosted directly on Atlassian.com.

If this is not known, we are unable to retrieve the PDF downloads on a restricted network.

h3. Suggested Solution

Please include a note or reference for those on restricted networks that the PDF documentation resides elsewhere to open up network access.
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/alldoc/applications-and-tools-documentation-directory-209586313.html
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/atlassian-cloud-ip-ranges-and-domains-744721662.html
fields.summary: Update documentation to include reference PDF download location

fields.description:
h3. Summary Malformed URL generated with "//" when adding content to a Review via "Edit Details" h3. Environment Crucible = Any Support Version (found in latest) OS = Any (Win, Linux, MAC) Browser =(Chrome, FireFox, IE) h3. Steps to Reproduce # Open or create a Review in Crucible ** Start review if needed ** To see the "//" we will need use the browsers devtools inspect the requests and responses # Select {{Edit Details}} # In your browsers devtools select "Network" # Select "edit-details" name under network activity to view response (this is a POST but, if you get a 302 you may need to view the next GET ) ** At bottom of response you see {{"baseUrlSuffix": "/"}}if no default repo *OR* \{\{"baseUrlSuffix": "/"}} # Select Add Content button # Select Browse Changesets # You will find a GET request for the repository or for "/" if no repo. View the Header information and you will see "//" in the URL h3. Expected Results The URL should not contain "//" h3. Actual Results # edit-details response {noformat} {"errorMsg":"", "worked": true, "payloadHtml": "
Suggest reviewers...
Wiki syntax help Preview
", "baseUrlSuffix": "/~user=sauce1173/clone" } {noformat} # GET request for the repository {noformat} Request URL:[http://dude.office.atlassian.com/fisheye/cru/TST-1/edit-changelog//~user=sauce1173/clone] Request Method:GET Status Code:200 OK Remote Address:X.X.X.X:80 {noformat} It is possible that the malformed URL could cause an infinite loop if your proxy is not able to parse the "//". h3. Workaround If the malformed URL causes an issue within your ENV. You can workaround this issue by: Adding content by using the plus symbol "+" from the Review Details Page on the lefthand Side[\{
fields.summary: Malformed URL generated with "//" when adding content to a Review via "Edit Details"

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Multiple users can edit review details at the same time.  This can lead to problems where users can delete each other out of the reviewer leaving no one in the list.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a review with users A and B who have edit permissions and are reviewers.
# User A - open the Review Details page.
# User B - open the Review Details page.
# User A - remove user B from the reviewer list.
# User B - remove user A from the reviewer list.
# User A - save the review.
# User B - save the review.

h3. Expected Results
Only 1 user can edit review details at a time

h3. Actual Results
Changes overlap
 
h3.Workaround
Use Permission Schemes to limit *Edit Review Details* to one user.
fields.summary: Multiple users can edit the review details at the same time

fields.description:
When backup is performed, some Lucene indexes are being closed (--FE-3635--), but Crucible review index stays running. This causes problems when trying to run backup with "repository and application caches" option enabled as  {{cache\cruidx\idx1\write.lock}} exists and cannot be accessed. The problem exists on Windows machines only.

 

*Steps to reproduce*

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The "Hardware requirements" and "Disk space requirement estimates" paragraphs are not available in the Crucible documentation ([Crucible Supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/supported-platforms-298977375.html]) while they are in the FishEye documentation ([FishEye Supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/supported-platforms-298976955.html]).

h3. Suggested Solution
Add the missing paragraph to the Crucible documentation. 

h3. Workaround
Refer to the FishEye documentation ([FishEye Supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/supported-platforms-298976955.html]).
fields.summary: As an admin, I want the "Hardware requirements" and "Disk space requirement estimates" paragraphs to be available in the Crucible documentation.

fields.description:
h4. Problem
SVN has lots of limitations in comparison to Git, one of them is a limited branching features.
 Crucible can detect when the branch was created (copied) but it doesn't detect when it was synchronized with other branch. In fact each file modification on the branch we sync from is considered as a file modification on the current branch. However a new file addition won’t be added to the review and we have a bug for it (CRUC-6262).

h4. Workarounds
 * Create a review from changesets (excluding sync ones). If you have a small amount of commits it should be simple
 * Create a patch review
 * Create a branch review but manually remove all synced files. You may consider using [this plugin|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.fecru.plugins.fecru-batch-frx-management-plugin/server/overview]
fields.summary: Branch review from SVN repo contains unwanted files

fields.description:
Some customer find it confusing if there is an unpublished review that does not contain a title.

 

Steps to reproduce:
 * Press "Create review" blue button. A dialog with a drop down menu and "Default Project (CR)" is displayed.
 * Press "Create Review". A dialog with multiple options is displayed
 * Press "Browse change set"
 * Select a commit
 * Press "Edit details". You see the Title that matches commit message.
 * Press "Done". Instead of the title of the review you actually see "Untitled"
 * Refresh page and you see that title has changed to the expected one (same as in "Edit details").

Expected: after pressing "Done" you should see the Commit message as Title, not "Untitled".
fields.summary: Stale review title on review page when Edit Review action changed it

fields.description:
h2. Problem Definition

When performing a code review, clicking anywhere on a text line opens up the inline comment box. The click could be an attempt to highlight the particular code for discussion purposes during a review, or may be done accidentally when scrolling through the code due to a faulty laptop mouse pad.

As a user, I would like to be able to disable this functionality for my user profile.
h2. Suggested Solution

Allow users to disable the inline commenting to assist them to best navigate and work within the tool.

Alternatively, a hover option off to the side of the line number could allow the user to launch the inline comment box.
h2. Workaround

When viewing the diff, users can select {{FishEye}} from the drop down and select {{View File Diff}}. This will transition the user from the Crucible review diff to the FishEye review diff and allow the user to highlight text without any additional comment boxes loading.
fields.summary: Allow users to disable inline comments on reviews

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When "Store the contents of file in reviews" is selected for a Project and a new review is created, the contents of the review are expected to be stored so that if the repository is removed, the files are still available in the review.  Not all file contents are stored immediately when the review is created leading to a race condition where, if a review a has a large number of files and the repository is removed, only some of the files are still available. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create Project with "Store the contents of files in reviews" checked.
# Create a review that contains approx 50 files.
# As soon as the review is created, delete the associated repository.
# Go back into the review and look at the contents.

h3. Expected Results
All file contents are still available in the review

h3. Actual Results
Only some of the files' contents are available with the rest showing the message "Sorry, we can't display this file: Repository <Repository Name>- does not exist"
 
h3.Workaround
Reconnect the repository and then visit all files in the review to make sure the contents are stored.
fields.summary: "Store the contents of files in reviews" race condition

fields.description: Some customer have a preferred project to create a review into. The feature is to be able to set a default project to be pre-selected upon creating a review in Crucible, but to still allow review creator to amend if necessary.

fields.description:
h4. Summary
In CRUC-7262 we made a change that only the first line of a commit message is used as review title when review is created for a changeset.

For some use cases, e.g. for clients using SVN [bugtraq|https://tortoisesvn.net/docs/release/TortoiseSVN_en/tsvn-dug-bugtracker.html] issue tracking hooks, this might be non ideal, as the first line of a commit message contains only the issue key, and no meaningful text.

h4. Have your say
It is yet unclear what solution we should apply.
Please vote on this issue if you'd like a change to the review title extraction mechanism. 
Please comment on your specific use case.

h4. Custom solution
As there might be no solution that would satisfy every use case, it might be feasible for users to write their own commit hook plugin to extend the off the shelf [Smart Commits|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/using-smart-commits-298976812.html].
To see an example of a plugin, see [Smart Commit Tutorial|https://developer.atlassian.com/fecrudev/tutorials/fisheye-smart-commit-tutorial].
Use [ReviewService|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/javadoc/com/atlassian/crucible/spi/services/ReviewService.html] to create a review.
If you experience a difficulty writing your plugin, it's best to use [Atlassian Answers|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/topics/754116/crucible-development] to post your question.
fields.summary: Improve commit message -> review title mapping

fields.description:
Below are some changes in the UI which would make processes quicker and easier to work with, in the experience of this user:

*ADDING LATEST ARTIFACTS TO REVIEW*
 # If a review is currently open have the option to add the latest revision for all artifacts (instead of manually having to add the latest for all artifacts)
 # Have a unique icon for artifacts that are not on the latest file (e.g. outdated)
 # Have the “Add latest file” button closer to artifacts, or with hotkey (it is a lot of mouse work to move from artifact to add latest file, back to the next artifact, to add latest file, etc.)

*COMMENTARY*

 # Ability to respond to comments on previous revisions without having to go to the revision it was made on by hovering over the red icon signifying a comment was made on a prior revision. When an artifact has lots of revisions it can be easy to lose track of comments and then figure out which revision the comments are visible/respondable on
 # Place the SVN revision of the artifact noted on the comment when a comment is made

*ADDING ARTIFACTS*
 # When adding artifacts from the repository, make it possible to select all files in a folder instead of individually clicking them

CC: [~imran.perwez1300916394]
fields.summary: UI Improvements

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The "View" dropdown is not available for any review based on pre-commit patches.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a review
# Add a pre-commit patch (git in the example below)

h3. Expected Results
The "View" dropdown is available as in the previous versions of Crucible.

The screenshots below have been generated with version 4.2.1.

+"View" dropdown with a review in Edit mode+
 !CRUC7958_421_EditMode.png|width=600px! 

+"View" dropdown with a review in *non* Edit mode+
 !CRUC7958_421_NonEditMode.png|width=600px!


h3. Actual Results
The "View" dropdown is *not* available.

+"View" dropdown missing with a review in Edit mode+
 !CRUC7958_430_EditMode.png|width=600px! 

+"View" dropdown missing with a review in *non* Edit mode+
 !CRUC7958_430_NonEditMode.png|width=600px!


h3.Workaround
The view defaults can be changed for each individual user profile by accessing the {{User Icon (in the top right corner of the screen) -> Profile settings}} and changing the {{Diff view -> Context lines}} option.
Other options are available as well in the same dialog.

h3. Notes
- The "View" dropdown is still present for other type of patches (non pre-commit).
- The "View" dropdown is displayed for patches uploaded prior to the upgrade (e.g. created in 4.2.1).
- The "View" dropdown is not displayed for patches uploaded after the upgrade to existing reviews (created prior to the upgrade)
fields.summary: View dropdown not available for reviews based on pre-commit patches

fields.description:
As Crucible user I want to have a better universal inbox which lists all
 # reviews I need to complete
 # reviews I need to close
 # comments I received an answer to (I haven't read yet) 
 # (unread) comments I was mentioned in using @mention functionality
 # new unread comments (unread and read) in open or closed reviews I'm either author or reviewer.
 # my non-closed code snippets

so
 # I don't miss anything in reviews
 # I don't need to fallback to email notifications which partially duplicate what I already process in Crucible.
 # No time is wasted on processing in both Crucible an Gmail.

 

This can be called "Inbox" and replace existing "Inbox" you have in Crucible since existing is not practical due to the reasons highlighted.

"Archive" action similar to Gmail should be present so if I'm fine with specific comment then I can archive (acknowledge) it. Read/unread is different flow - if comment is read it means I read it but have not yet processed/acknowledged. That's why you have "Archive" feature in e.g. Gmail.

If at certain point the reviewer was removed from review then comments they added before should be in such "Inbox" unless they archived it. Currently if reviewer is removed from review then they can only access comments via email notifications or searching for such review in Crucible. But that's error-prone.

[PL-1339|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/PL-1339] is a similar story but was closed for some reason. See it for more details.
fields.summary: Crucible Inbox

fields.description:
From discussion in CRUC-98:

{quote}
Michael Armstrong added a comment
So the implementation in version 4.2 seems to be lacking a state.  If Al make a comment and marks it as needing resolution.  Then Betty implements it and marks it as resolved.  When Al comes back in, if he doesn't like the resolution, he can reopen it, but what happens if he likes the resolution.  How does he indicate that he reviewed the change and likes it? Does he have to make a new comment?  Seems like another state of approved or verified or reviewed or some such would be useful.  

Marek Parfianowicz added a comment 
Hi Michael, thanks for your feedback.
Let me ask a question:
why Al can't just leave the comment as is (i.e. in the resolved state) if he likes the resolution?
I'm asking because:
new commits added to a review are marked as unread, so you can easily find new content added
new comments as well as changes in the resolution state are marked as unread, so you can easily find them too
So:
"resolved" + "unread" = fix waiting a review
"resolved" + "read" = fix is approved
"resolved" -switch to-> "needs resolution" = fix is rejected

Michael Armstrong added a comment
Maybe some of this is my background.  We are a company coming from a much more formal review processes, so I'm used to having a very positive action that lets a reviewer accept or reject an implementation.  
This issue I have with relying on the read or unread state of the comment is that the implementer can't see the reviewer's read/unread status.  The implementer has no way to know if the reviewer hasn't seen the implementation yet or saw it an approved it.  
{quote}
fields.summary: Add possibility to approve or reject comments having the "Resolved" state

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
 
When evaluating Crucible, FishEye is automatically evaluated. This can be misleading when businesses want to only evaluate Crucible.  

We have a warning during installation, however, if you aren't the person who installed Crucible you wouldn't know this. 

!fisheye.png! 


h3. Suggested Solution

Either use an opt in process during the installation or have a banner warning that FishEye is enabled. 
  
h3. Workaround

We do have steps on disabling FishEye during a Crucible evaluation in [How to disable FishEye during the evaluation of Crucible?|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/how-to-disable-fisheye-during-the-evaluation-of-crucible-646186097.html].
fields.summary: Create opt in or out option for FishEye evaluation

fields.description:
This mostly applies to situation where a patch (diff) content is copied from a terminal window. A typical diff generated via {{svn diff --git}} command is in form of:
{code:java}
Index: trunk/c.txt
===================================================================
diff --git a/trunk/c.txt b/trunk/c.txt
--- a/trunk/c.txt       (revision 237)
+++ b/trunk/c.txt       (working copy)
@@ -219,3 +219,4 @@
 aa
 aa
 aa
+new line
{code}
where in _from_ and _to_ lines a path part (e.g. {{a/trunk/c.txt}}) is separated from a revision part ({{(revision 237)}}) with a tab ({{\t}}) character. When copying from terminal, tab can get replaced by a series of spaces which fools Crucible into treating a revision part as an extension of a path component:

!image-2017-01-11-09-33-31-140.png!
fields.summary: Crucible doesn't correctly handle SVN patches in Git format with spaces instead of tabs
Show related file's or code review's branch so it's easier for developer to understand to which branch changes are related to

fields.description:
Comment workflow in Crucible 2:
 * Type in the comment
 * Post it

Comment workflow in Crucible 4:
 * Type in the comment
 * Check an additional "Needs resolution" check box to have your comment taken seriously
 * Post it

Since the vast majority of comments are things we do want resolved, I think that new comments should be marked as unresolved by default.

This is also how it is on other sites with a similar workflow, such as Google Docs.

 

If there is someone out there who posts comments that don't need to be resolved, like posting memes or jokes in their comments, then letting them manually uncheck the box is fine. They're the minority anyway, and they're already wasting time by posting such comments, so a little additional time to check a box is not going to hurt.
fields.summary: Add a "Needs resolution as default" option in user preferences dialog

fields.description:
Commit messages generally contain a JIRA ID so that you can follow it to the ticket and read the background.

In Crucible, the JIRA ID is now hyperlinked to an "Authenticate to see this issue" error box, which when attempting to authenticate, does not actually work, and does not take me to the issue.

In the older version, it used to just be a hyperlink, which just worked. It seems like doing it the obvious way, as a normal hyperlink, was superior to whatever "clever" thing Atlassian changed it to, which doesn't.
fields.summary: "Authenticate to see this issue" does not actually let me see the issue

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

FishEye fails to index Bitbucket Server repositories if the environment variable {{GIT_SSH_COMMAND}} is set:

{noformat}
2016-12-03 18:44:25,348 WARN  [IncrPing2 repo ] fisheye IndexingPingRequest-doRequest - Exception during FishEye Incremental Indexing of repo (repo): com.cenqua.fisheye.config.ConfigException: com.atlassian.fisheye.dvcs.handler.DvcsProcessException: Error while communicating with VCS: Permission denied (publickey).
    fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
    
    Please make sure you have the correct access rights
    and the repository exists. 
{noformat}

With the {{GIT_SSH_COMMAND}} variable being set, the {{fe-ssh.sh}} script is never executed meaning FishEye never makes the SSH call to Bitbucket Server.

h3. Suggested Solution

On start-up of FishEye/Crucible we should check if the environment variable {{GIT_SSH_COMMAND}} is set and prompt a warning to the user and or override with the usage of our own.

h3. Workaround

Manually unset the variable {{GIT_SSH_COMMAND}}.
fields.summary: If GIT_SSH_COMMAND is set, FishEye SSH does not execute to index Bitbucket Server Repo

fields.description:
h2. Steps to reproduce

# Have SVN repository with at least one branch and trunk
{noformat}
$ svn diff --summarize -r 1:8 file:///tmp/repository/project1/
A       file:///tmp/repository/project1/branches/branch-1/file
A       file:///tmp/repository/project1/branches/branch-1
A       file:///tmp/repository/project1/branches
A       file:///tmp/repository/project1/trunk/file
A       file:///tmp/repository/project1/trunk
{noformat}
{noformat}
$ svn log -v  file:///tmp/repository/project1/branches/branch-1/file
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r8 | glewandowski | 2016-12-14 12:26:56 +0100 (Wed, 14 Dec 2016) | 1 line
Changed paths:
   M /project1/branches/branch-1/file
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r7 | glewandowski | 2016-12-14 12:26:32 +0100 (Wed, 14 Dec 2016) | 1 line
Changed paths:
   M /project1/branches/branch-1/file
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r6 | glewandowski | 2016-12-14 12:26:14 +0100 (Wed, 14 Dec 2016) | 2 lines
Changed paths:
   A /project1/branches/branch-1 (from /project1/trunk:5)

Created branch-1
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r5 | glewandowski | 2016-12-14 12:26:03 +0100 (Wed, 14 Dec 2016) | 1 line
Changed paths:
   M /project1/trunk/file
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r4 | glewandowski | 2016-12-14 12:25:50 +0100 (Wed, 14 Dec 2016) | 1 line
Changed paths:
   M /project1/trunk/file
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r3 | glewandowski | 2016-12-14 12:25:35 +0100 (Wed, 14 Dec 2016) | 1 line
Changed paths:
   A /project1/trunk/file
{noformat}
# Create review
# Add content via _Explore repositories_
# Change _Add to Review as_ select to _Diffs to ..._
# Put _5_ (or any commit number which was made on trunk)
 !screenshot-3.png|thumbnail!

h2. Expected behaviour

Revisions {{project1/branches/branch-1/file@8}} and {{project1/trunk/file@5}} are added to review and diff generates properly between them or meaningful information is presented to a user.

h2. Actual behaviour

FishEye ignores logical paths for a file and fails with NPE.
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

Potentially the same problem exists for Perforce repositories 


There's a code which handles such situation when a revision is on a tag and completely disregards the situation like here when it's on a branch.
Code Snippet from {{com.cenqua.fisheye.svn.db.SvnRevInfoDAO#getRevId}}
{code}
public int getRevId(Path path, long changesetId) throws DbException {
        int revid = getPureRevId(path, changesetId);
        if (revid == -1 && pathMatcher.isTag(path)) {
            String tag = pathMatcher.getTag(path);
            Path logicalPath = getLogicalPath(path);
            revid = getTaggedPathRevid(logicalPath, tag, changesetId);
        }
        return revid;
    }
{code}

h2. Workaround

If user wants to generate diff to a branch point, simply se _Diff to branch point_
fields.summary: Crucible ignores logical paths when Diff To option is used

fields.description: If I have a file on trunk in subversion at revision X, and I create a branch, and the file undergoes changes on that branch and is at rev X+N, there doesn't seem to be a way to make Crucible have both revisions X and X+N in the same file side-by-side view. Rather, Crucible has one file on trunk with revision X, and one file of same name on other branch with revision X+N. Very impractical. Subversion provides such diffs (just open the revision graph and select any two nodes) so there isn't even any work for crucible to do, if it can delegate the diffing to SVN.
fields.summary: Add revision from different branch

fields.description:
Currently we're trying to anchor a file to a repository. As an added step we could try to anchor a patch to an existing revision in the review. This would allow the following example scenario to work:
 * Have an original file in a repository (PasswordResetMailTest.java)
 * Create a review and add patch #1 containing the following copy operation: "PasswordResetMailTest.java" > "PasswordResetMailTest-copy.java"
 * Add patch #2 to the review containing modification of "PasswordResetMailTest-copy.java"

As we're only trying to anchor to repository, patch #2 won't be currently anchored as there's no "PasswordResetMailTest-copy.java", so we end up with two paths in the repository:

!image-2016-12-12-13-47-59-951.png!

If it was possible for a patch to be anchored to a revision in a review (not yet existing in a repository), consecutive iterations of "PasswordResetMailTest-copy.java" changes could be presented as a single changes stream.
fields.summary: Enable anchoring patches to review
Lines added/removed displayed as nulls on upload patch screen

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When creating a JIRA Issue from a review, only the "Project", "Issue Type", "Summary" and "Description" fields are presented.  If there are any fields designated as required in JIRA, issue creation will fail
h3. Environment

JIRA 6 and Crucible 4
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create Project in JIRA
 # Specify a field as "Required"
 # Create a review in Crucible
 # Add a comment in Crucible
 # Click "Create Issue"
 # Fill in the presented fields.
 # Click "Create"

h3. Expected Results

The "Create Issue" screen presents any required fields from the JIRA Project.
h3. Actual Results

No required fields are presented. 
h3. Workaround

Remove the "Required" property from all fields in JIRA.
fields.summary: Required JIRA Issue fields are not displayed when creating an issue from a review

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When adding a new commit to an existing review, if the commit contains a file, for which a previous commit, also added to this review, have been removed, the file gets duplicated in the review.

h3. Environment
* Observed for Git repositories.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a commit, adding a file to it (e.g. TestFile.java).
# Create a new review, adding the commit previously created to the review.
# Remove the commit previously created from your Git repository, then let Crucible index the change. This commit can be removed by a rebase/force push.
# Create a new commit that also contains the file {{TestFile.java}}.
# Add this new commit to the review.

h3. Expected Results
* Crucible identifies there has been a change to {{TestFile.java}} and adds a new iteration for this file to the review.

h3. Actual Results
* Crucible adds {{TestFile.java}} as a new file, and the file appears duplicated in the review.
fields.summary: Adding a new commit to a review duplicates an existing file if the original commit of the file has been removed

fields.description:
h2.  
h2. Current behaviour

1. Have one comment thread

           !image-2016-12-02-13-04-41-965.png!  

         Where _reply 2_ comment has higher internal database ID than the parent comment (_test 1_) 

            !image-2016-12-02-13-06-34-044.png!

        (This seems like inconsistent state which should not happen, we couldn't determine the root cause of such)

2. Go to that Review.

3. Javascript execution is broken due to error thrown from Crucible Review Activity Plugin 

!image-2016-12-02-13-09-22-395.png|width=722,height=219!

The _DataBridge_ code assumes that comments will always be ordered with an order where parent comment is always first before reply comments. This isn't true.

  !image-2016-12-02-13-12-13-590.png|width=785,height=185!
h2. Expected Behaviour

Crucible handles the different comments ordering and renders review page correctly.
h2. Workaround

The bug is happening in _crucible-review-activity-plugin _so in order to perform the review which has problems because of it, it's OK to temporarily disable the plugin.

 

In order to disable plugin:
 # Go to {{Administration}} {{->}} {{Manage Add-ons}}
 # Change Add-on filter to {{All add-ons}}
 # Find _crucible-review-activity-plugin _and disable it

  !image-2016-12-02-13-21-36-016.png|width=538,height=314!
fields.summary: When Comment has higher ID number than it's parent then Review Activity plugin fails to initialise

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If a Customer is using Crucible 4.2 only (no FishEye license), the following warning messages are displayed in the logs:
{noformat}2016-10-05 15:11:20,557 WARN - The repository index for Repository (Repository) does not match the repository configuration - using configuration from current index 
{noformat}
While there is _no_ impact from these warning messages and can be safely ignored, they are displayed if you have store-diff set to true but your cache is set to false. Changes on ----CRUC-7629---- indicate that the ignoring of the false flag was to be fixed, but in this scenario, it continues to be ignored.
h3. Environment
 * Crucible 4.2

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Generate a mix of cache store-diff value being false while the store-diff value on the repository is set to true.
 # Alternatively, install Crucible 4.2 specifically (and having only the Crucible license applied), and add a repository.

h3. Expected Results
 * Store-diff is unchecked or set as false

h3. Actual Results
 * Store-diff defaults to true (or checked in the UI) when manually adding a repository, or pulling from Bitbucket Server.
fields.summary: Store diff is not set to false (or unchecked) when using Crucible only

fields.description:
h2. Actual behaviour

Currently when any perforce related error happens when FishEye tries to get [p4 describe -dn|https://www.perforce.com/perforce/r15.2/manuals/cmdref/p4_describe.html] for a batch of changesets, it fallbacks and tries to get the data for changesets one-by-one. If this fail, FishEye will try to call _p4 describe -s_ and if this will fail again FishEye will ignore given changeset as it wouldn't exist in a repository. This will lead to missing changesets information and FishEye repository model won't represent actual repository structure. 

FishEye will log the following message to log files:
{noformat}Removing changelist 321{noformat}
 

However, the bug can present itself long after the log file rotates and log message is already gone. This lead to hardly reproducible problems which are nightmare to find the root cause. Missing changeset information can have an impact on whole FishEye&Crucible products, e.g. file ancestries, commit graphs, diff generation.

 
h2. Expected behaviour 

FishEye correctly handles which come from Perforce, correctly fallbacks from batch mode and does not loose any changeset information. In case of persistent errors, propagate the exception into upper callee levels.
fields.summary: Incorrect error handling with Perforce can lead to missing changeset in FishEye repository data

fields.description:
h2. Actual behaviour

Currently when any perforce related error happens when FishEye tries to get [p4 describe -dn|https://www.perforce.com/perforce/r15.2/manuals/cmdref/p4_describe.html] for a batch of changesets, it fallbacks and tries to get the data for changesets one-by-one.

If this fail, FishEye will try to call _p4 describe -s_ which lists only basic information about changeset and don't provide diff information which is required to calculate lines added and removed for a file revision in changeset.

 

This result in incorrect lines added/removed counters and potentially can lead to blame calculation errors further in the indexing process

!image-2016-12-01-09-01-35-031.png!

Correct changeset information:

!image-2016-12-01-09-02-09-804.png!
h2. Expected behaviour 

FishEye correctly handles errors which come from Perforce, correctly fallbacks from batch mode and propagates the exception if it can't get the required information from perforce.
fields.summary: Incorrect error handling with Perforce can lead to missing lines added/removed counters for a file revisions
Incorrect error handling with Perforce can lead to missing metadata for some file revisions

fields.description:
If a team wants to use the reviewer's Complete button to say "I the Reviewer am done a pass, Author you please take a look", then there is no way for the author to know when the review can be closed because the completion status is per reviewer and temporary. 

OTOH if the team wants to use the Complete button so a reviewer can say "No more issues", the reviewer has no way of letting the author know that the reviewer is done a pass. 

Either way, the author has no way of letting the reviewer know that the reviewer can once more look at the review.

What is needed is an intermediate state per reviewer, like Partially Complete. So the workflow would be like this: 
 # author creates review and assigns reviewers; each reviewer is "incomplete"
 # each reviewer finds incomplete reviews in their Incomplete box: those are reviews they need to look at
 # each reviewer works on an incomple review: adds defects, or marks already fixed defects as resolved, or adds reply to a fixed defect that cannot be accepted
 # reviewer Completes a review only if they have no issues left, but Partially Completes a review if the author needs to make some fixes
 # author can look at their Partially Complete box to find reviews that need their attention; if there are more than 1 reviewer, a review will be in that box if at least one reviewer as partially completed
 # Author uncompletes each reviewer after fixes requested by that reviewer are done
 # reviewer sees uncompleted reviews and can look at the fixes. If all accepted, reviewer completes, else partially completes and the cycle continues. 
 # As now, a review appears in the Completed box only when ALL reviewers have completed their review. 

So all that is needed is an additional reviewer state "Partially Completed", an additional action "Partially complete" available to each Reviewer, and a new box Partially Completed in the Dashboard. Then
 * the author knows to look in their Uncompleted box for reviews that need reviewer input, in their Partially Completed box for reviews that have fixes they (AUthor) to make for at least one reviewer, and their Completed box for reviews that can be closed.
 * A reviewer knows to look in their Uncompleted box for reviews to start or fixes to asses, in their Partially Completed box for which reviews they have kicked back to author, and in their Completed box for which reviews they are completely done with.
fields.summary: New state needed for reviewers: Partially Complete

After upgrading from 2.x to 4.x, emails from Crucible now come with the subject pre-truncated:

{{Subject: [FishEye and Crucible] ACME-CODE-19870: Thingy: allow the sort order to b...}}

This is not particularly helpful. Mail clients will already truncate the subject for display, but if the sender truncates it, now I can't even see the whole subject if I want to.

fields.description:
When a p4 patch is created and contains no newline at the end of the file that was added or deleted, the following patch line is included in the new file and the modification in the next file is lost.   

e.g.:(
{noformat}--- /dev/null 
+++ //im/appliance/platform/main/apps/services/security/scripts/yastAD.pl.src (revision 1)
@@ -0,0 +1,674 @@
+#!/usr/bin/perl
+# ApplianceVersionFile= (#) NBAPP_
<672 lines>
+=cut
+... depotFile //im/appliance/platform/main/apps/soa/security/SPECS/security.inst
{noformat}
 
 In this example, the yastAD.pl.src file has as its last line ...depotFile */security.inst and that file is not included in the review.
h3. Cause

There is a bug in P4Source#get_add and P4Source#get_delete methods in {{crucible.py}} script, see comment below.
h3. Workaround

Create and upload patches manually, using command line.  The workaround to include added files is explained in [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Creating+patch+files+for+pre-commit+reviews#Creatingpatchfilesforpre-commitreviews-p4-added-file]
fields.summary: patch file with added or deleted file with no newline at the end causes next file to be lost in Crucible reviews

Often on large reviews with many comments I don't want to mark every comment as read when I scroll past it.  It makes it hard to determine which comments I've actually read and which comments I still need to read.

It would be very nice to have an option to control this behavior, similarly to the "Auto mark files as read" option.

I found the following post from someone having the same difficulties as me but I couldn't find any issues the author may have created: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/11990322/how-to-turn-off-mark-comments-as-read-by-scrolling
fields.summary: Need ability to turn off 'mark comments as read by scrolling'

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The "Allowed review participants" option in the project settings isn't restricting the scope for groups when searching for reviewers to be added to a review, therefore all the groups are listed, even the ones not included as allowed groups.
h3. Environment
 * Tested on Crucible 4.2.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Have a few groups added to Crucible (e.g. *group1* and *group2*).
 # Edit the project settings, selecting only *group1* under *Allowed review participants*, then save the configuration.
 # Create a review and click in *Edit Details*.
 # Click on the *Reviewers* field.

h3. Expected Results
 * Only group1 and its members will be shown.

h3. Actual Results
 * Both group1 and group2 are listed.
 * The scope restriction still works for users. They also apply when only a specific group is set as an allowed reviewer, i.e. even though group1 and group2 are listed, only users from group1 are listed below the groups list.
fields.summary: "Allowed review participants" isn't restricting the scope for groups
